newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: HK's Lee sees China fear in Australian refusal.
newsitem.headline: HK's Lee sees China fear in Australian refusal.

text.p: Hong Kong democracy campaigner Martin Lee said on Monday that diplomatic fears of offending China may have led Australia's Prime Minister John Howard to refuse a formal meeting with him.
"People in the foreign office (may have) thought a meeting with me would upset China tremendously," Lee, chairman of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, told reporters.
"I am not saying this is Mr Howard's view, but I can certainly see this might be the foreign office's view."

Lee, who is lobbying Canberra to apply diplomatic pressure on Beijing over its treatment of Hong Kong, said he had been invited to meet Howard only at a cocktail party that he would have trouble attending.
A spokesman for Howard said the prime minister's schedule was too busy to accommodate a private meeting.
China, which will resume sovereignty of the British colony at midnight on June 30 next year, is setting up an interim replacement for Hong Kong's democratic Legislative Council.
Lee says the new assembly is intended to merely rubber stamp Beijing's wishes.
He will meet Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer on Tuesday.
